div.p: Dear D205 Families,

Thank you for your support and involvement as parents in the District 205 remote e-learning process during this time. Today’s Remote Professional Learning Day provided strong opportunities for our faculty and staff to collaborate and continuously improve our academic procedures and provide the necessary support and learning opportunities for our students.
The purpose of this communication is to provide additional specific information related to our evolving plans for remote e-learning, including:

li.p: Reminder of Attendance Procedures
Parent & Student Input on Remote E-Learning
Guidance for Parents on Feedback, Assignments, and Grades

div.p: As we continue to improve our approaches, notices and updates will be made available through the “Find it Fast” menus on each schools’ website.

p.strong: 1. Reminder of Attendance Procedures

div.p: For EC-5 Parents: Monday-Thursday, between 8-11 a.m. parents need to complete the Daily E-Learning Attendance Check-In for Parents EC-5. If a parent is unable to check-in a student, the student will be marked as an “Unexcused Absence.”

For 6-12 Students: Thank you for helping remind our students that on Monday-Thursday between 9-11 a.m., students in grades 6 to 12 must use their district-issued Chromebook, home computer, or mobile device to log into Google Classroom at https://classroom.google.com and follow the directions in the Daily E-Learning Attendance Directions for Students 6-12 to submit their attendance. If a student is unable to mark themselves present by 11 a.m., the student will be marked as an “Unexcused Absence.”

For All Parents: Similar to a typical school day, if a student is ill or unable to participate in the E-Learning Day, parents and guardians must call the school attendance line by 11:00am to report an absence from e-learning. NOTE: On Fridays, parents and students will not be required to log/call in for attendance, nor submit any learning evidence, as the days are designated for remote professional learning.

p.strong: 2. Parent & Student Input on Remote E-Learning
p.br: For EC-5 Parents: Thank you to over 700 parents and family members of students in grades EC-5 able to share survey feedback about their experiences so far with remote e-learning.

li.p: What’s going well: Our teachers and our families are working incredibly hard to support their students. Many parents thanked specific teachers for their responsiveness and care and 90 percent of students are getting feedback from teachers daily or every few days. The second week of e-learning has brought more specific and tailored assignments directly from teachers to help advance learning and parents report that as a positive development. A few parents even mentioned that despite the stress of trying to balance their own jobs, other children, and family needs, the opportunity to get to know their children as learners and become more familiar with their work was a welcome impact during this challenging time.

Where we can improve: Students miss their teachers, their friends, and their classmates. Providing more interactions (short and pre-scheduled) with students was a common suggestion for improvement. Another common suggestion was to clarify which course areas and assignments are priorities and which are optional. Finally, students have access to many tools and websites to learn from - but navigating all the links, logins, and notifications is a challenge.

div.p: For 6-12 Parents: Last week, about 2,900 students in grades 6-12 shared their experiences so far with remote e-learning.

li.p: What’s going well: Most students reported that e-learning is “going fine.” Eight-five percent of students are getting feedback daily or every few days from their teachers. Many students also mentioned an appreciation for the autonomy over their schedules and the flexibility to work at their own pace.

Where we can improve: Current guidance from the ISBE regarding the recommended length of sustained attention for students during remote e-learning suggests middle school students should spend a maximum of 3 hours per day and high school students up to 4 ½ hours per day on schoolwork. But over forty percent of students report spending more time than this. For students feeling stress, having too much work was the most common source of that stress. Though most students report being able to do their work independently, many students also want more opportunities to connect with teachers online.

p.strong: Next Steps for District 205

li.p: The section that follows is intended to clarify expectations regarding assignments, feedback, and grades for parents - including information about which subject areas are optional extension opportunities, as well as the frequency of feedback and grades.
We will be working with our school leaders and technology department to discuss ways to simplify navigating online tools.

Teachers and administrators will use time during the upcoming remote planning Fridays to discuss how to continuously improve the balance of assignments for students as well as technology and other related opportunities for virtual interaction.

p.strong: 3. Guidance for Parents on Feedback, Assignments, and Grades
p.br: Teachers will continue to provide feedback on student work in key content and skill areas, including formative feedback aimed at improvement and feedback that indicates a student’s level of performance (grades or scores). Student learning and demonstrations of learning in a remote setting may look different than in-person work, and will require flexibility on the part of teachers and students.

div.p: As a reminder, guidance from the Illinois State Board of Education indicates that student grades prior to the transition to remote learning (as of 3/13/2020) can only be maintained or improved, provided the student demonstrates continued engagement and ability at a passing level after the transition to instructional remote learning day. In accordance with this guidance, D205 would like to share the following details for clarity and awareness.

p.strong: For EC-5 Parents & Students

li.p: Students in grades EC-5 are asked to “send one (1) piece of evidence for literacy and one (1) piece for math per day of remote learning from any of the work done directly to their teacher - either by email or SeeSaw” (Please reference the Remote E-Learning Weekly Menu Sample Template).
If unable to upload or send evidence of learning, parents are encouraged to contact the teacher or case manager.

Teachers will continue to provide feedback where appropriate. Similar to learning in the classroom, not every piece of evidence submitted by students will be used for grading; some will be used as formative information for teachers and students.
Teacher teams are working to identify at least one key assignment per week in English Language Arts and math that will be used for trimester 3 grading.

All activities for Specials in grades K-5 (Art, Music, PE, Media Specialists, and Spanish in Grades 3-5) are optional extension opportunities for students to complete. These extension opportunities will be updated each week by teachers to provide engagement and enrichment. Students may send evidence of learning to Specials Teachers if they choose for feedback; yet, they are intended to serve as optional extension experiences for students.

p.strong: For 6-8 Parents & Students

li.p: Teacher teams are working to identify key assignments each week to be graded. For courses that do not meet daily, such as Science and Social Studies, teacher teams are identifying at least one assignment to be graded every other week.
Letter grades will be provided to students in grades 6-8 at the end of the second semester.

The following courses in grades 6-8 are optional extension opportunities for students to complete. These extension opportunities will be updated each day by teachers to provide engagement and enrichment. Students may send evidence of learning to the teacher(s) if they choose for feedback; yet, they are intended to serve as optional extension experiences for students.
Band, Orchestra, Choir, World Language, Music, Art, PE/Health, Creative Tech, Industrial Tech, Family and Consumer Science, and Project Lead the Way.

p.strong: For 6-12 Parents & Students (How Grades are Calculated)

li.p: Teachers will continue to provide feedback where appropriate. Similar to learning in the classroom, not every piece of evidence submitted by students will be used for grading; some will be used as formative information for teachers and students.
A new term in the gradebook called “C1” will reflect student grades up to 3/13/2020, which was the last day of in-school learning.
For most courses, assignments and grades added after 3/13/20 (during remote e-learning) will appear in a term for second semester called “S2.”
Students and parents will see C1 and S2 information in PowerSchool to help students and families understand how grades are improving.
Student grades CANNOT go down as a result of remote e-learning, so at the end of the semester, teachers will assign either the C1 or S2 grade, depending on whichever is higher.
For clarity, please note that a student’s temporary semester 2 grade (S2) may fluctuate - going down and up during remote e-learning, as shown in the figure that follows.

Yet, assignment grades cannot harm the student’s overall grade as it was on 3/13/2020. The assignment grades can only help improve the student’s overall grade, as illustrated in this example where the student’s grade was 88% on 3/13/2020 and then eventually 91% (at the future final semester 2 grade).

div.p: Should parents have questions, please reach out to our dedicated teachers. As we continue to adapt academically, I would like to again thank our learning community for their support in taking care of one another during this time, and for the ongoing focus on health and wellness together.

Sincerely,
Dr. David Moyer
Superintendent

hr.p: Estimadas Familias del Distrito Escolar 205,

Queremos expresar nuestro agradecimiento por su apoyo e involucramiento como padres de familia del Distrito escolar 205, dentro del proceso del aprendizaje remoto y a distancia que estamos viviendo en estos momentos. El día de hoy hicimos el primer Día de Aprendizaje Profesional Remoto para todo el Profesorado y Personal, con el mismo, hemos traído oportunidades a todo nuestro personal docente y administrativo para mejorar nuestros procedimientos académicos y brindar oportunidades de apoyo al aprendizaje para todos nuestros estudiantes.
El propósito de este comunicado es proveer información específica relacionada con los planes que involucran el aprendizaje remoto o a distancia, incluyendo:

li.p: Recordatorio y Procedimientos de Asistencia Virtual Diaria
Opinión de los Padres y Estudiantes en el Aprendizaje Virtual y a Distancia
Guía para los Padres de acuerdo a a la Retroalimentación,las Tareas y Calificaciones

hr.p: Al mismo tiempo que continuamos mejorando nuestros procedimientos, brindaremos la oportunidad de encontrar la información y actualizaciones en el área de búsqueda de nuestra página web bajo la frase en inglés “Find it Fast” en el menú principal.

p.strong: 1. Recordatorio y Procedimientos de Asistencia Virtual Diaria

hr.p: Para los Padres de Educación Temprana hasta el Quinto Grado (EC- 5º): De lunes a Jueves de 8:00-11:00 a.m. los padres de familias necesitan completar los pasos detallados en la siguiente conexión: Daily E-Learning Attendance Check-In for Parents EC-5. Si el padre de familia no tiene la oportunidad de checar la asistencia virtual de su hijo(a), el estudiante estará siendo marcado con una Ausencia Injustificada o “U”.

Para los Padres de Estudiantes de Sexto a Doceavo (6º - 12º): Muchas gracias de antemano por recordarles a sus hijos que, de lunes a jueves entre 9:00-11:00 a.m. deben de poner su asistencia, ya sea con la computadora portátil, Chromebook que el Distrito les prestó, o la computadora de la casa o cualquier dispositivo de tecnología que tengan disponible para entrar a los salones virtuales de Google, mejor conocidos como Google Classroom en la conexión https://classroom.google.com y por favor, siga las instrucciones diarias que a continuación detallamos, Daily E-Learning Attendance Directions for Students 6-12. Si el estudiante no puede marcar su asistencia virtual para las 11:00 am, el estudiante será marcado con una Ausencia Injustificada o “U”.

Para Todos los Padres de Familia: De manera similar a un día típico escolar, si el estudiante está enfermo o ausente para participar desde su casa en el día escolar de Aprendizaje Virtual, los padres de familia o tutores tiene que notificarnos antes de las 11:00 am a través de la línea telefónica de ausencias de su respectiva escuela school attendance line. Nota: Todos los viernes han sido destinados para aprendizaje profesional de los profesores, por lo tanto, no es requisito que los padres, ni estudiantes entren a los salones virtuales, ni que llamen por teléfono.

p.strong: 2. Opinión de los Padres y Estudiantes en el Aprendizaje Virtual y a Distancia
Para los Padres de Educación Temprana hasta el Quinto Grado (EC-5º):

hr.p: Muchas gracias a los 700 padres de familia que han externado su opinión sobre la experiencia de aprendizaje virtual y a distancia en el sondeo de opinión que hicimos hace poco.

li.p: Lo que está funcionando: Nuestros profesores y familias están trabajando arduamente para apoyar a los estudiantes. Ha habido muchos padres de familia que han agradecido directamente a algunos profesores por su respuesta y cuidado, y 90% de los estudiantes han tenido respuesta del profesorado de manera diaria o casi diaria. La segunda semana del aprendizaje virtual ha traído tareas y trabajos más específicos moldeados a las necesidades de los estudiantes, que han sido elaborados para que los estudiantes avancen en su aprendizaje; los padres han reportado ésto como algo positivo. Incluso algunos padres de familia expresaron que, a pesar del estrés de tratar de balancear sus trabajos en casa y otros niños, más las necesidades familiares, han apreciado y se han dado cuenta de una manera positiva del proceso en el que sus hijos están aprendiendo.

Áreas en las que podemos mejorar: Nos damos cuenta de que los estudiantes extrañan a sus maestros, amigos y compañeros de clase. Una sugerencia que nos ha llegado fue la de promover y mejorar más interacción (corta o pre-organizada en el horario) con otros estudiantes. Otra sugerencia común fue la de clarificar qué cursos, áreas y tarea tienen prioridad y cuáles son opcionales. Finalmente y sabiendo que los estudiantes tiene acceso a muchas herramientas y páginas de internet, se nos ha notificado que ha sido un gran desafío navegar las conexiones, notificaciones y entrada a dichas páginas.

hr.p: Para los Padres de Estudiantes de Sexto a Doceavo (6º - 12º): La semana pasada, 2900 estudiantes de entre los grados 6º y 12º compartieron su experiencia sobre el aprendizaje remoto,

li.p: Lo que está funcionando: La mayoría de los estudiantes reportó que el aprendizaje virtual les está funcionando. 85 % de estudiantes está recibiendo respuesta de sus profesores de manera diaria o en un par de días. Muchos estudiantes mencionaron su aprecio a la nueva autonomía y flexibilidad de decidir sus propios horarios y de hacer sus tareas a su propio paso.

Áreas en las que podemos mejorar: La guía actual del Departamento de Educación del Estado de Illinois, ISBE por sus siglas en inglés, recomienda que la duración del aprendizaje remoto, es de 3 horas máximo diario para un estudiante de secundaria; y de 4 ½ horas diarias para un estudiante de preparatoria, sin embargo más de 40% de los estudiantes reportaron que están pasando muchas más horas en el aprendizaje remoto. Para los estudiantes, el estrés está directamente relacionado con la carga de trabajo académico, aunque la mayoría reportó que han podido trabajar de manera independiente y quieren más oportunidades de conectarse con sus profesores en línea.

p.strong: Siguientes Pasos para el Distrito 205

li.p: La siguiente sección tiene la intención de clarificar a los padres de familia cuáles son las expectativas relacionadas con las tarea, la retroalimentación y las calificaciones, incluyendo información acerca de qué materias o áreas son opcionales y cuáles son aquellas con oportunidades de extensión de tiempo para entregar dichas tareas. Así mismo incluimos la frecuencia de la retroalimentación y las calificaciones.
Estamos trabajando con nuestros líderes escolares y con el Departamento de Tecnología para discutir maneras de simplificar las herramientas de navegación en línea.

El profesorado y los administradores usarán todos los viernes para planeamiento y discusión de cómo mejorar y balancear nuestros procesos de tareas para todos los estudiantes, así mismo, como la tecnología y otras oportunidades relacionadas con la interacción virtual.

p.strong: 3. Guía para los Padres, Retroalimentación, las Tareas y Calificaciones

hr.p: Nuestros profesores continuarán proveyendo oportunidades de retroalimentación acerca del trabajo del estudiante en aquellas áreas de especial contenido y destrezas importantes que necesitan aprender. Incluyendo retroalimentación formativa canalizada a que el estudiante mejore y en aquellas áreas que indican el desenvolvimiento del estudiante (grados y calificaciones). El aprendizaje del estudiante y demostraciones de su aprendizaje en la educación a distancia o de manera remota pueden verse diferente que en persona, y requieren la flexibilidad por parte de los profesores y estudiantes.

Como recordatorio, la guía del Departamento de Educación del Estado de Illinois indica que los grados de los estudiantes antes de entrar y en transición a un medio de aprendizaje remoto (antes del 3/13/2020), sólo pueden mantenerse o mejorarse si se involucra y habilita al estudiante de manera continua para transicionar al período de aprendizaje remoto. De acuerdo a los lineamiento de dicha guía, el Distrito 205 quiere compartir los siguientes detalles para dar claridad y concientizar a la comunidad escolar:

p.strong: Para los Padres de Educación Temprana hasta el Quinto Grado (EC-5º):

li.p: Se les ha pedido a los estudiantes de entre los grados de EC al 5º enviar una prueba o evidencia de su trabajo en Lectura y Escritura, y una prueba de su trabajo en Matemáticas, ya sea por correo electrónico a su profesor, o por la Aplicación SeeSaw (Por favor use la tabla contenida en la siguiente conexión para su referencia Remote E-Learning Weekly Menu. .
Si no puede mandar pruebas de su trabajo en casa, le recomendamos a los padres de familia contactar directamente al profesor de sus hijos o al gerente del caso escolar de su estudiante.

Los profesores continuarán dando su retroalimentación cuando sea apropiada, de manera similar a los días en los salones de clase, no cada trabajo presentado al profesor será usado para las calificaciones finales, parte del trabajo es formar y enseñar al estudiante y parte es usado para información de conforme al estudiante y oriente al profesor del nivel del estudiante.

Los profesores están trabajando en identificar por lo menos una tarea importante a la semana para las clases en las áreas de Inglés, Lengua y Literatura, y una para el area de Matematicas, las mismas serán usadas para brindar calificaciones en el trimestre.

Todas las actividades para las clases adicionales de enriquecimiento (Arte, Música, Deporte, Medios de Comunicación y Español) en los grados de Kínder a 5º se les brindará la oportunidad opcional de completarse con extensión de tiempo. Estas oportunidades de extensión serán actualizadas cada semana por los profesores como manera de proveer involucramiento y enriquecimiento. Los estudiantes pueden mandar pruebas de su aprendizaje a los diferentes profesores de estas materias especiales de enriquecimiento. Si los profesores dan una retroalimentación será con la intención y la opción de dar una extensión y servir como una opción de enriquecimiento.

p.strong: Para los Padres de Estudiantes de Sexto a Doceavo (6º - 12º):

li.p: Los equipos de profesores están trabajando para identificar aquellas tareas importantes que serán calificadas cada semana. Para aquellos cursos que no necesitan hacer diario, como Ciencias Sociales o Ciencias Naturales, los equipos de profesores están identificando por lo menos una tarea que sea calificada cada dos semanas.
Se proveerán boletas o cartas con calificaciones a los estudiantes entre los grados 6º y 8º al final del segundo semestre.

Las siguientes materias en los cursos del 6º al 8º grados, tendrán una extensión de tiempo opcional para ser completados. Estas oportunidades de extensión de tiempo serán actualizadas diariamente por los profesores para proveer oportunidades de involucramiento y enriquecimientos. Los estudiantes pueden mandar pruebas de su aprendizaje al profesor si necesitan una retroalimentación, sin embargo, estas materias están consideradas como de enriquecimiento para los estudiantes.

ul.li: Banda, Orquesta, Coro, Idiomas, Música, Arte, Educación Física y Deportes, Salud, Tecnología Creativa, Industrial, Ciencias del Consumidor y el Proyecto de Enriquecimiento: Muestra el Camino o conocido como Project Lead the Way.

p.strong: Cómo se Calcularán los Grados para los Estudiantes de 6º - 12º

li.p: Los profesores continuarán ofreciendo retroalimentación cuando sea apropiado. De manera similar a los salones de clase, no todas las pruebas o evidencias entregadas por los estudiantes serán usadas para calificar, algunas son usadas para brindar información formativa entre estudiantes y maestros.
Se usará una nueva abreviación de calificación, “C1”, la misma refleja el grado anterior al sistema abierto de educación a distancia o de manera remota. (Antes del 3/13/2020).
Para la mayoría de los cursos, tareas y calificaciones añadidos después del 3/13/2020, durante la etapa de educación a distancia o remota del segundo semestre en el que estamos, se usará “S2”.
Los estudiantes y los padres de familia verán diferentes códigos entre C1 y S2 en el portal de PowerSchool para ayudar a los estudiante y las familias a entender en qué nivel están.

ul.li: Los estudiantes NO PUEDEN bajar sus calificaciones como resultado del aprendizaje remoto, así que al final del semestre, los profesores asignarán ya sea, C1 o S2 como calificación, dependiendo cuál sea mayor.

li.p: Para clarificar, por favor tome nota que el grado del segundo semestre es temporal y puede fluctuar, subir y bajar durante este período de aprendizaje remoto, como lo muestra la gráfica más adelante.

Asimismo, los grados asignados no pueden perjudicar al promedio general del estudiante que tenía hasta el 13 de marzo del 2020. Los grados otorgados sólo pueden mejorar el promedio general como se ilustra en el siguiente ejemplo, donde el promedio general de un estudiante era del 88% alcanzado hasta el 13 de marzo y eventualmente, 91% (al final del segundo semestre como segundo promedio general).

hr.p: Si algún padre de familia o tutor tiene alguna pregunta, por favor no dude en acercarse a nuestros profesores que son muy diligentes y dedicados. Mientras nos estamos adaptando académicamente hablando, me gustaría una vez más, expresar mi agradecimiento a toda la comunidad escolar por su apoyo incondicional entre familias y por el continuo enfoque a la salud y al bienestar en conjunto.
Sinceramente,

Dr. David Moyer

div.p: April 17, 2020
Dear D205 Families,

A link to a video version of this message is available here. This afternoon, Illinois Governor J.B. Pritzker issued a statement in which he suspended in-person learning for the remainder of the 2019-20 school year. At the April 28th Elmhurst Community Unit School District 205 Board of Education meeting, the administration will present the board of education with options to consider for how District 205 moves forward with upcoming events such as graduation and summer school. Separate communications will be developed and released early next week with detailed information about athletics, activities, and other activities that were originally scheduled for or postponed until May.

Today was the first of five remote professional learning days for teachers. The purpose of these days is to give teachers the time to plan engaging and meaningful lessons for students, develop strategies to support students and families, ensure consistency of expectations for the amount of work students are being asked to do and the manner in which feedback is provided and grades are determined, and to increase the teachers’ collective ability to leverage digital tools in ways that promote rigor, personalization of learning, and student engagement. I emphasized these things when I addressed the teachers this morning, and reiterated the importance of trying to find creative ways to personally connect with students.

In his address, the governor stated that, “the unprecedented circumstances” dictate that grades should be about feedback, not a tool for compliance. Today’s communication provides updated information on assessment during this period of remote learning and should serve to provide clarity on how grades will be calculated at each grade level. If you have additional questions, please direct them to your child’s teachers.
All of our families are in my thoughts and prayers every day. Stay well.

Dr. David Moyer
Superintendent
Elmhurst Community Unit School District 205

hr.p: 17 de Abril, 2020
Estimadas Familias del Distrito Escolar 205,

Pritzker emitió una declaración en la que suspendió el aprendizaje en persona por el resto del año escolar 2019-20. div.p: April 15, 2020
Dear D205 Families,

Thank you for your feedback shared through the recent District 205 Remote E-Learning Surveys. Our goal is to improve the delivery of instruction and the learning process as students engage with their peers and teachers from home due to Illinois Governor J.B. Pritzker’s “Stay at Home” Order, which closed school campuses and facilities statewide through April 30, 2020. We appreciate your understanding as we remain responsive and flexible to implement real-time enhancements during this pathbreaking time in education amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

ISBE State Superintendent Dr. Carmen Ayala declared Remote Learning Days for schools beginning March 30 until school resumes. During this dispensation, districts are allowed to use up to five Remote Planning Days in partnership with their collective bargaining units. The days count toward the minimum length of the academic year and do not need to be made up. Last evening, the Board authorized the use of five Remote Professional Learning Days in D205.

These days will be scheduled on Fridays from April 17 through May 15 as long as schools are closed. This shift is designed to allow teachers adequate time to work with their colleagues and individually prepare more meaningful learning plans. The initial focus will be on improving consistency of implementation and developing strategies to interact more effectively with students and families. In turn, remote professional learning days also will allow parents greater flexibility to support their child’s learning by using Friday as a day of study in order to complete assignments or projects from the week.

Students will not be required to log-in for attendance or submit any learning evidence on remote professional learning days. However, these planning days may be used to conduct IEP meetings when scheduled. You should continue with your learning plan for the week until you receive updated information from your child’s teachers.

The COVID-19 pandemic has impacted each D205 family and staff member to varying degrees. As the days out of school accumulate, the impact on our school community only stands to grow. Each day, we must balance the basic and essential needs of health, safety and wellness with the fervor to advance learning. We believe this decision will better support meaningful learning experiences for our children, tempered with a compassion for the challenges that our families are facing.
Thank you for your input as our leadership team and teachers continue to be responsive to your concerns and evolve in this new environment.
Sincerely,

Dr. David Moyer
Superintendent
Elmhurst Community Unit School District 205

hr.p: 15 de abril de 2020
Estimadas familias del Distrito Escolar D205:

Gracias por sus recientes comentarios que compartieron a través de las recientes encuestas remotas de aprendizaje electrónico del Distrito 205. Nuestro objetivo es mejorar la entrega de instrucción y el proceso de aprendizaje a medida que los estudiantes trabajan con sus compañeros y maestros desde sus casas debido a la Orden de "Quedarse en Casa" del Gobernador de Illinois JB Pritzker, quien cerró las escuelas e instalaciones escolares en todo el estado hasta el 30 de abril de 2020. Nosotros apreciamos su comprensión, ya que seguimos siendo receptivos y flexibles para implementar mejoras inmediatas durante este tiempo sin precedencia en la educación dentro de la pandemia de COVID-19.

La Superintendente Estatal de ISBE, la Dra. Carmen Ayala, declaró Días de Aprendizaje Remoto para las escuelas a partir del 30 de marzo hasta que volvamos a clases. Durante esta dispensación, los distritos pueden usar hasta cinco días de planificación remota en asociación con sus unidades de negociación colectiva. Los días cuentan para la duración mínima del año académico y no necesitan reponerse. Anoche, la Junta autorizó el uso de cinco días de aprendizaje profesional remoto en nuestro distrito escolar.

Estos días se programarán los viernes del 17 de abril al 15 de mayo, mientras que las escuelas estén cerradas. Este cambio está diseñado para dar a los maestros el tiempo adecuado para trabajar con sus colegas y preparar individualmente planes de aprendizaje más significativos. El enfoque inicial será mejorar la consistencia de la implementación y desarrollar estrategias para interactuar más efectivamente con los estudiantes y las familias. A su vez, los días de aprendizaje profesional a distancia también permitirán a los padres una mayor flexibilidad para apoyar el aprendizaje de sus hijos al usar el viernes como día de estudio para completar las tareas o proyectos de la semana.

En estos viernes, no se requerirá que los estudiantes inicien sesión para asistir o presenten evidencia de aprendizaje, usted no tendrá que marcar la asistencia de su hijo/a. Sin embargo, estos días de planificación pueden usarse para llevar a cabo reuniones de IEP cuando estén programadas. Ustedes deben continuar con su plan de aprendizaje durante la semana hasta que reciba información actualizada de los maestros de su hijo/a.

La pandemia de COVID-19 ha impactado a cada familia del D205 y a los miembro del personal de diferentes maneras. A medida que se acumulan los días fuera de la escuela, el impacto en nuestra comunidad escolar va a continuar. Cada día, debemos equilibrar aún más las necesidades básicas y esenciales de salud, seguridad y bienestar para avanzar en el aprendizaje. Creemos que esta decisión respaldará mejor las experiencias de aprendizaje significativas para nuestros hijos, moderandolas con compasión por los desafíos que enfrentan nuestras familias.
Gracias por su aporte ya que nuestro equipo de liderazgo y maestros continúan respondiendo a sus inquietudes y mejorando en esta nueva situación.
Sinceramente,

Dr. David Moyer
Superintendente
Unidad Escolar Elmhurst Distrito Escolar 205

div.p: April 10, 2020
Dear D205 Families,

Please find a link to today's video here. Hello! I appreciate all of you who took the time to respond to the D205 Remote Learning Survey. Your feedback is important to us. As our teachers learn and grow in this new environment, we will strive to improve our ability to support our families and foster meaningful learning experiences for our children.

Yesterday, I met with our administrative team and stressed that the District’s priority is to ensure that our families and employees are healthy and safe. I emphasized that again in a letter to our staff. I am cognizant of the fact that every day that the school closure continues, families face increasing challenges balancing personal, job and educational expectations, and that many of our families are dealing with hardship and loss. We are here to support you.

I also have reiterated to teachers the importance of adhering to the time parameters that students are expected to engage from home. In addition, my team and I are working to strengthen our ability to assess and provide feedback for students without obsessing, and having students and parents obsess, over the idea of “grades.” To me, this adds unnecessary stress and anxiety to a situation that is already stressful for our families.

It is a holiday weekend for many of us. For those of you who are celebrating, I hope you enjoy your family and spiritual renewal. I cannot stress enough the importance of adhering to social distancing guidelines even as you move through this special weekend.
Again, we will adapt to the future learning challenges over the summer and into next school year. The immediate goal is to take care of each other. Please continue to stay well.
Sincerely,

Dr. David Moyer
Superintendent
Elmhurst Community Unit School District 205

! Les agradezco a todos los que tomaron tiempo para responder a la Encuesta de aprendizaje remoto de nuestro distrito escolar Su opinión es importante para nosotros. A medida que nuestros maestros aprenden y crecen en este nueva manera de enseñar, nos esforzaremos para mejorar nuestra capacidad de apoyo a nuestras familias y así fomentar las experiencias de aprendizaje más significativas para nuestros hijos.

Soy consciente del hecho de que cada día que continúa el cierre de las escuelas, las familias enfrentan desafíos cada vez mayores al tener equilibrar las expectativas personales, laborales y educativas, y también sé que muchas de nuestras familias enfrentan dificultades y tal vez pérdidas de trabajo. div.p: Date: April 2, 2020
Dear D205 Families,

On behalf of Elmhurst Community Unit District 205, I hope the past few weeks have allowed your families and students to remain healthy and home together as much as possible in these challenging times.
The purpose of this communication is to provide important updates related to our evolving plans for remote e-learning procedures, including:

li.p: Plan for Continuity of Instruction
Improvements in Grades EC-5
Improvements in Grades 6-12
Instructional Tool Enhancements & Important Parent Considerations
Grading and Assessment Procedures
Student Engagement & Recommended Length of Sustained Attention

div.p: As we progress, future notices and updates will be made available through the “Find it Fast” menus on each schools’ website.

p.strong: 1. Plan for Continuity of Instruction
p.br: Yesterday, D205 staff members reviewed a comprehensive plan designed to continue academic activities while mitigating the effects of disruptions caused by COVID-19. The plan included expanded guidelines regarding roles and responsibilities for staff including special education and related service providers, assessment and grading guidelines for all levels, supports and strategies for staff, and digital tools for staff. This plan advances our curriculum and learning as much as possible while maintaining support for our students during these unprecedented times.

p.strong: 2. Improvements in Grades EC-5 (Starting Monday, April 6)
p.br: Starting Monday, April 6, students in grades EC-5 will no longer use the pre-planned E-Learning Menu Module from 3/30 - 4/3. Instead, teachers will provide a more personalized approach for each week of learning through a Remote E-Learning Weekly Menu (Sample Template).

li.p: Grade-level teams of teachers on a weekly basis at each school to create, adapt, and remotely deliver lessons in the areas of literacy, math, and specials (art, music, PE, and Spanish for applicable grades). For students participating in early childhood programming, a similar developmentally-appropriate menu here will be developed each week.

For the week of April 6 - April 10, parents will receive their child’s Remote E-Learning Weekly Menu by Sunday evening (April 5). For subsequent weeks of instruction, parents can expect to receive the Remote E-Learning Weekly Menu from their child’s teacher by 5:00pm each Friday to review in advance of the next week of remote e-learning.

Parents can also expect continued communication and support from teachers, including new opportunities for student-to-teacher connections as highlighted in the section below on Remote E-Learning Instructional Tool Enhancements.

p.br: Remote E-Learning procedures for Grades 6-12 will continue as currently designed with teachers posting assignments by 9:00 am each day utilizing Google Classroom.

li.p: Students in grades 6-12 will be receiving an electronic survey to gather feedback regarding the remote e-learning experience so far. The student input will be used to make future adjustments to district procedures.

For students previously identified for intervention and additional support in ELA and/or math, parents can expect more frequent communication from teacher(s), as well as one-on-one and/or small group instruction opportunities via district-approved communication technologies.

p.br: The following adjustments to instructional tools have been made to enhance remote learning while maintaining protection and privacy for our students.

p.strong: Elementary (K-5)

td.p: Enabled for email within elmhurst205.org and to/from teachers only.
K-5 students are not able to communicate via email externally and are not able to email each other.
Enabled for video conferencing on a session that has been established by a teacher only.
K-5 students are not able to start Google Meet sessions.
For Grades 2-12+: GoGuardian Teacher is enabled on student Chromebooks and Chrome browsers at home.

GoGuardian Teacher is a classroom management tool that allows teachers to “look over a student’s shoulder” to supervise and support, schedule classroom sessions, interact with students, push web pages, block web pages, monitor student learning activities, etc.

p.strong: Middle School (6-8)

td.p: Enabled for email within elmhurst205.org.
6-8 students are not able to communicate via email externally but they are able to email each other directly.
Enabled but restricted to sessions that have been established by a teacher.
6-8 students are not able to start Google Meet sessions.

p.strong: High School (9-12)

td.p: Google Gmail and Google Meet are enabled for students to interact internally and externally without the restrictions that are in place for K-8.

div.p: As a reminder, technical support will be available from school and District 205 technology staff by emailing ELearningHelp@elmhurst205.org. This email is operational on designated E-Learning Days only and actively monitored between 7:30 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. When an email is submitted, a work ticket will be created and assigned to the appropriate staff member. Parents and students should contact teachers or case managers for curricular or instructional questions.

p.br: The virtual classroom is like the regular classroom. Other members of a student’s household may be present during and even participate in the classroom environment, just like they might at school. Any person who participates in the virtual classroom, including your student, will be held to the same standards of behavior that would apply inside a classroom in the school building. If you have questions about what these expectations are, contact a building administrator for more information.

div.p: Please remember that during classroom instruction, audio and video recordings and photography are not allowed without specific permission from an administrator or the teacher. The same applies to our remote learning instruction. Do not make audio or video recordings of remote learning instruction or take photographs of your child during instruction, which include any staff member or other students without express permission from the staff member delivering the instruction or an administrator. If you receive such recordings or photographs from a source other than the District, delete them and do not post or forward. We appreciate your cooperation.

p.b: 5. Remote E-Learning Grading and Assessment Procedures
p.br: District 205’s approach to feedback, assessment of student work, and grading is aligned to guidance provided by the Illinois State Board of Education (ISBE) and designed to focus attention on key standards, ensure maintenance of existing knowledge and skills, and extend that knowledge and skill as much as possible in a remote environment. To that end, students and families should expect that teachers will provide feedback on student work in key content and skill areas, including formative feedback aimed at improvement and feedback that indicates a student’s level of performance (grades or scores). Student learning and demonstrations of learning in a remote setting may look different than in-person work, and will require flexibility on the part of teachers and students.

div.p: Guidance from ISBE indicates that student grades prior to the transition to remote learning can only be maintained or improved, provided the student demonstrates continued engagement and ability at a passing level after the transition to instructional remote learning day. In accordance with this guidance, D205 will assign final term grades based on a comparison of a student’s grade as of March 13, 2020 and the grade obtained at the end of the term including remote e-learning assignments. The higher of the two grades will be assigned as final. Note that during remote e-learning, students may be able to redo or make up some assignments from prior to 3/13/20, in collaboration with teachers, in order to improve their grades.

Students who do not engage in remote e-learning (e.g. not completing key, necessary assignments) may receive a grade of incomplete after multiple documented attempts by teachers and administrators to reach out to the students and families. Every effort will be made to work with students and families to provide opportunities for engagement that take into account individual or unique circumstances. More specific information by grade level follows:

p.strong: Early Childhood

td.p: For trimester 3, students and parents will receive report cards with information for the following measures: LLD 9 Letter & Word Knowledge; LLD 10 Emergent Writing; and, COG 3 Number Sense and Quantity. All others will be labeled unable to rate (UR).

p.strong: Elementary (K-5)

td.p: For trimester 3, students and parents will receive report cards with standards-based scores in a subset of standards in math and English language arts (ELA). For math, the standards will be based on where school teams are in the math curriculum. For ELA, 3-5 focus standards per grade for remote e-learning will be determined by the district. Using information from key assignments in those areas, teachers will assign final trimester 3 standards grades on the subsets of standards. Grades from trimester 2 will be assigned for those standards if higher than grades in those standards received in trimester 3. Process standard scores will not be assigned. Specials courses (art, music, Spanish) will be graded as pass/incomplete.

p.strong: Middle School (6-8)

td.p: For semester 2 final grades, teachers will review student grades as of 3/13/20, compare to the end-of-semester grade that incorporates remote e-learning assignments, and choose the higher grade. A specific grading term in the gradebook that ends as of 3/13/20 will be set up for this purpose. Students with a grade of F or more than one standards-based score of 1 in a course at the end of the semester (who did not have a higher grade as of 3/13), may earn a grade of incomplete. This grade will remain incomplete in a student’s final record unless additional arrangements are made with the student’s teacher prior to the end of the year and any remaining work submitted in accordance with a plan agreed upon by the teacher (and student and parent/guardian). Elective and exploratory wheel courses such as art not already completed by 3/13 will be graded as pass/incomplete.

p.strong: High School (9-12)

td.p: For semester 2 final grades, teachers will review student grades as of 3/13/20, compare to the end-of-semester grade that incorporates remote e-learning assignments, and choose the higher grade. A specific grading term in the gradebook that ends as of 3/13/20 will be set up for this purpose. Students with a grade of F in a course at the end of the semester (who did not have a higher grade as of 3/13), may earn a grade of incomplete. This grade will remain incomplete in a student’s final record unless additional arrangements are made with the student’s teacher prior to the end of the year and any remaining work submitted in accordance with a plan agreed upon by the teacher (and student and parent/guardian). If the student does not make up the incomplete, the student will be assigned no grade (NG) and will not earn credit for the course. Seniors must have successfully completed all of the credits required for graduation (i.e. with at least a grade of pass) in order to graduate.

p.b: 6. Student Engagement & Recommended Length of Sustained Attention
p.br: These District 205 guidelines for maintaining student engagement during remote learning were developed following guidance provided by the Illinois State Board of Education (ISBE) on March 27, 2020. The thresholds in the table below are inclusive of activity, reflection, and collection or completion of learning evidence. This may also include project time that spans multiple days, independent work, and direct teacher engagement.

td.p: Early Childhood
3-5 minutes
Kindergarten
3-5 minutes
5-10 minutes
10-15 minutes
Class: 15 minutes/day Total: 90 minutes/day
Class: 30 minutes/day Total: 180 minutes/day
1 subject area or class
Class: 20 minutes/day Total: 120 minutes/day
Class: 45 minutes/day Total: 270 minutes/day
1 subject area or class

div.p: Further, teachers may be providing periodic additional optional work, engagement opportunities, and enrichment opportunities - all of which will not negatively impact a student’s grade.

By incorporating and adapting guidance provided by the Illinois State Board of Education, District 205 continues to improve and support remote learning procedures that meet local needs and, to the greatest extent possible, minimizes the negative impact this unprecedented moment has on our students’ educational futures.
Sincerely,

Dr. David Moyer
Superintendent
Elmhurst Community Unit School District 205

hr.p: Estimadas Familias de D205,

En nombre de la Unidad Comunitaria Elmhurst Distrito 205, espero que estas pocas semanas pasadas hayan permitido que sus familias y estudiantes se mantengan saludables y juntos en casa tanto como sea posible en estos tiempos difíciles.
El propósito de esta comunicación es proporcionar actualizaciones importantes relacionadas con nuestros planes en evolución para los procedimientos remotos de aprendizaje electrónico, que incluyen:

ol.li: Plan para la Continuación de la Instrucción
Mejoras de Herramientas de Instrucción y Consideraciones Importantes para los Padres
Participación de los Estudiantes y Duración Recomendada de Asistencia Sostenida

hr.p: A medida que avanzamos, los avisos y actualizaciones futuras estarán disponibles a través de los menús "Encuéntrelo Rápido/Find it Fast" en el sitio web de cada escuela.

p.strong: 1. Plan para la Continuación de la Instrucción

hr.p: Ayer, los miembros del personal de D205 revisaron un plan integral diseñado para continuar las actividades académicas mientras mitigan los efectos de las interrupciones causadas por COVID-19. El plan incluyó pautas ampliadas con respecto a los roles y responsabilidades del personal, incluida la educación especial y los proveedores de servicios relacionados, pautas de evaluación y calificación para todos los niveles, apoyos y estrategias para el personal, y herramientas digitales para el personal. Este plan avanza nuestro plan de estudios y aprendizaje tanto como sea posible mientras mantiene el apoyo a nuestros estudiantes durante estos tiempos sin precedentes.

p.strong: 2. Mejoras para los Grados EC-5 (a partir del lunes 6 de abril)

hr.p: A partir del lunes 6 de abril, los estudiantes en los grados EC-5 ya no usarán el plan planificado previamente en el módulo E-Learning Menu Module del 3/30 al 4/3. En su lugar, los maestros proporcionarán un enfoque más personalizado para cada semana de aprendizaje a través de un Remote E-Learning Weekly Menu (plantilla de muestra).

li.p: Equipos de maestros de nivel de grado semanalmente en cada escuela van a crear, adaptar y brindar lecciones de manera remota en las áreas de literatura, matemáticas y especiales (art, música, educación física y español para las calificaciones correspondientes). Para los estudiantes que participan en programa de pre escolar, un menú similar de desarrollo apropiado aquí se desarrollará cada semana.

Para la semana del 6 al 10 de abril, los padres recibirán antes el menú semanal de aprendizaje electrónico remoto de sus hijos, el domingo por la noche (5 de abril). Para las siguientes semanas de instrucción, los padres pueden esperar recibir el Menú Semanal de Aprendizaje Electrónico Remoto del maestro de su hijo antes de las 5:00 pm cada viernes para revisar antes de la próxima semana de aprendizaje electrónico remoto.

Los padres también pueden esperar una comunicación continua y el apoyo de los maestros, incluidas nuevas oportunidades para las conexiones de estudiante a maestro, como se destaca en la sección a continuación sobre Herramientas Educativas de Aprendizaje Electrónico Remoto/Remote E-Learning Instructional Tool Enhancements.

p.strong: 3. Mejoras para los Grados 6-12

hr.p: Los procedimientos remotos de E-Learning para los Grados 6-12 continuarán según lo diseñado actualmente con los maestros publicando las tareas a las 9:00 a.m.todos los días utilizando Google Classroom.

li.p: Los estudiantes en los grados 6-12 recibirán una encuesta electrónica para recopilar comentarios sobre la experiencia remota de aprendizaje electrónico hasta el momento. El aporte del estudiante se utilizará para hacer ajustes futuros a los procedimientos del distrito.

Para los estudiantes previamente identificados para intervención y apoyo adicional en ELA y/o Matemáticas, los padres pueden esperar comunicaciones más frecuente de los maestros, así como oportunidades de instrucción individual y/o en grupos pequeños a través de tecnologías de comunicación aprobadas por el distrito.

p.strong: 4. Mejoras en las Herramientas de Instrucción

hr.p: Los siguientes ajustes a las herramientas de instrucción se han realizado para mejorar el aprendizaje remoto mientras se mantiene la protección y la privacidad de nuestros estudiantes.

p.strong: Grado
Google Mail
Google Meet
GoGuardian Teacher
Elemental (K-5)

td.p: Se puede enviar por correo electrónico dentro de elmhurst205.org de/y/a maestros solamente.
Los estudiantes de K-5 no pueden comunicarse por correo electrónico externamente y no pueden enviarse correos electrónicos entre sí.
Habilitado para videoconferencia en una sesión establecida sólo por un profesor.
Los estudiantes de K-5 no pueden iniciar sesiones de Google Meet.
Para Grados 2-12 +: GoGuardian Teacher está habilitado en Chromebooks y navegadores Chrome para estudiantes en casa.

GoGuardian Teacher es una herramienta de gestión de la clase que permite a los maestros “mirar sobre el hombro de un estudiante” para supervisar y apoyar, sesiones de programación de aula, interactúan con los estudiantes, páginas de inserción Web, bloqueo de páginas web, las actividades de aprendizaje de los estudiantes del monitor, etc.

p.strong: Escuela Secundaria (6 -8)

td.p: Habilitado para correo electrónico dentro de elmhurst205.org.
6-8 estudiantes no pueden comunicarse por correo electrónico externamente, pero pueden enviarse correos electrónicos entre sí directamente.
Habilitado pero restringido solo para sesiones establecidas por un profesor.
6-8 estudiantes no pueden iniciar sesiones de Google Meet.

p.strong: Preparatoria (9-12)

td.p: Google Gmail y Google Meet están habilitados para que los estudiantes interactúen interna y externamente sin las restricciones vigentes para K-8.

p.br: Como recordatorio, el personal de tecnología de la escuela y el Distrito 205 estará disponible por correo electrónico en ELearningHelp@elmhurst205.org. Este correo electrónico está operando solo en los días designados de E-Learning y se monitorea activamente entre las 7:30 am y las 4:00 pm. Cuando envía un correo electrónico, se creará un ticket de trabajo y se asignará al miembro del personal apropiado. Los padres y los estudiantes deben comunicarse con los maestros o administradores de casos para preguntas curriculares o instructivas.

p.strong: Consideraciones Importantes para los Padres
p.br: El aula virtual es como el salón normal de clase. Otros miembros del hogar de un estudiante pueden estar presentes e incluso participar en el ambiente del aula, tal como lo harían en la escuela. Cualquier persona que participe en el aula virtual, incluido su estudiante, tendrá los mismos estándares de comportamiento que se aplicarían dentro de un aula en el edificio escolar. Si tiene preguntas sobre cuáles son estas expectativas, comuníquese con un administrador de su edificio para obtener más información.

hr.p: Recuerde que durante la instrucción en el aula, las grabaciones de audio y video y la fotografía no están permitidas sin el permiso específico de un administrador o el maestro. Lo mismo se aplica a nuestra instrucción de aprendizaje remoto. No haga grabaciones de audio o video de la instrucción de aprendizaje remoto ni tome fotografías de su hijo durante la instrucción, lo que incluye a cualquier miembro del personal u otros estudiantes sin el permiso expreso del miembro del personal que entrega la instrucción o un administrador. p.strong: 5. Procedimientos de Calificación y Evaluación del Aprendizaje Electrónico Remoto

hr.p: El enfoque del Distrito 205 para la retroalimentación, la evaluación del trabajo de los estudiantes y la calificación está alineado con la orientación proporcionada por la Junta de Educación del Estado de Illinois (ISBE) y diseñado para centrar la atención en los estándares clave, garantizar el mantenimiento de conocimiento y habilidades existentes y se extienda ese conocimiento y habilidad tanto como sea posible en un entorno remoto. Con ese fin, los estudiantes y las familias deben esperar que los maestros brinden retroalimentación sobre el trabajo del estudiante en áreas clave de contenido y habilidades, incluida la retroalimentación formativa dirigida a la mejora y la retroalimentación que indica el nivel de rendimiento del estudiante (calificaciones o puntajes). El Aprendizaje del estudiante y las demostraciones de aprendizaje en un entorno remoto pueden ser diferentes al trabajo en persona y requerirán flexibilidad por parte de los maestros y los estudiantes.

La orientación de ISBE indica que las calificaciones de los estudiantes antes de la transición al aprendizaje remoto solo se pueden mantener o mejorar, siempre que el estudiante demuestre compromiso y habilidad continuos a un nivel aprobatorio después de la transición al día de aprendizaje remoto de instrucción. De acuerdo con esta guía, D205 asignará las calificaciones finales del trimestre en función de una comparación de la calificación de un estudiante al 13 de marzo de 2020 y la calificación obtenida al final del período, incluidas las tareas remotas de aprendizaje electrónico. El más alto de los dos grados será asignado como final. Tenga en cuenta que durante el aprendizaje electrónico remoto, los estudiantes pueden rehacer o completar algunas tareas anteriores al 13/03/20, en colaboración con los maestros, para mejorar sus calificaciones.

Los estudiantes que no participan en el aprendizaje electrónico remoto (por ejemplo, no completan las tareas clave y necesarias) pueden recibir una calificación de incompleto después de múltiples intentos documentados por parte de maestros y administradores de comunicarse con los estudiantes y las familias. Se hará todo lo posible para trabajar con los estudiantes y las familias para proporcionar oportunidades de participación que tengan en cuenta las circunstancias individuales o únicas. td.p: Para el tercer trimestre, los estudiantes y los padres recibirán boletas de calificaciones con puntajes basados ​​en estándares en un subconjunto de estándares en matemáticas y artes del lenguaje inglés (ELA). Para las matemáticas, los estándares se basarán en la ubicación de los equipos escolares en el plan de estudios de matemáticas. Para ELA, el distrito determinará estándares de 3-5 del enfoque por grado para el aprendizaje electrónico remoto. Usando la información de las tareas clave en esas áreas, los maestros asignarán las calificaciones finales del tercer trimestre en los subconjuntos de estándares. Las calificaciones del trimestre 2 se asignarán a esos estándares si son más altas que las calificaciones en los estándares recibidos en el trimestre 3. No se asignarán las calificaciones estándar del proceso. Los cursos especiales (arte, música, español) se calificarán como aprobados o incompletos.

p.strong: Escuela Secundaria (6-8)

td.p: Para las calificaciones finales del semestre 2, los maestros revisarán las calificaciones de los estudiantes a partir del 13/03/20, las compararán con la calificación de fin de semestre que incorpora tareas remotas de aprendizaje electrónico y elegirán la calificación más alta. Para este propósito, se establecerá un término de calificación específico de las calificaciones con que se finalizó el 13/03/20. Los estudiantes con una calificación de F o más de una calificación estándar de 1 en un curso al final del semestre (que no obtuvieron una calificación más alta a partir del 3/13), pueden obtener una calificación de incompleta. Esta calificación permanecerá incompleta en el registro final del estudiante a menos que se hagan arreglos adicionales con el maestro del estudiante antes del final del año y cualquier trabajo restante presentado de acuerdo con un plan acordado por el maestro (y el estudiante y el padre/tutor). Los cursos electivos y exploratorios de la rueda, como el arte que no se hayan completado antes del 3/13, se calificarán como aprobados o incompletos.

p.strong: Preparatoria (9-12)

td.p: Para las calificaciones finales del semestre 2, los maestros revisarán las calificaciones de los estudiantes a partir del 13/03/20, las compararán con la calificación de fin de semestre que incorpora tareas remotas de aprendizaje electrónico y elegirán la calificación más alta. Para este propósito, se establecerá un término de calificación específico de las calificaciones con que se finalizó el 13/03/20. Los estudiantes con una calificación de F en un curso al final del semestre (que no obtuvieron una calificación más alta al 3/13), pueden obtener una calificación incompleta. Esta calificación permanecerá incompleta en el registro final del estudiante a menos que se hagan arreglos adicionales con el maestro del estudiante antes del final del año y cualquier trabajo restante presentado de acuerdo con un plan acordado por el maestro (y el estudiante y el padre/tutor). Si el estudiante no recupera lo incompleto, no se le asignará ninguna calificación (NG) y no obtendrá crédito por el curso. Los estudiantes de último año deben haber completado con éxito todos los créditos necesarios para la graduación (es decir, con al menos una calificación de aprobación) para poder graduarse.

div.p: Dear D205 Families and Staff,

You may view this message in video form here. I would like to begin by thanking all of our families and employees for their patience and cooperation as we launched E-Learning in District 205 yesterday.

This afternoon, Illinois Governor J.B. Pritzker extended the closure of schools across the state through the end of the month of April. This was not unexpected, and the District has been busy planning to transition from Act of God Days to extended Remote Learning Days. We will elicit feedback and learn from our first several days of implementation and will continue to work to improve our service to you.

The Illinois State Board of Education is recommending that all assessment during Remote Learning Days should be for the purpose of feedback. You can expect a communication soon with additional information on assessment and grades, special education services, and other pertinent information, including resources from our Student Services staff that may be helpful to families during this challenging time.

We will continue to make meals available to our families in need and work collaboratively with our local government agencies and health care providers to serve our community. As one example, I am proud of our schools’ recent efforts to provide supplies such as sanitary wipes, gloves and goggles to Edward-Elmhurst Hospital.

People also are becoming increasingly concerned about the continuation of athletics and end-of-year activities, such as prom, graduation, and summer school. We will begin planning for a variety of possibilities immediately, but we do not have enough information to provide details or make final decisions at this point.

The one thing I do know is: strict adherence to the social distancing measures and sanitation guidelines such as regular hand washing will help prevent illness and help all of us return to normal sooner rather than later.
In closing, I just want to tell you all how much I miss our students, staff and families. Please continue to take care and stay well.
Sincerely,

Dr. David Moyer

td.p: Dear D205 Families and Staff,

You can view this message in video form here. As we prepare to launch our e-learning initiative in District 205 beginning Monday, March 30, we also continue to prepare for the likelihood that schools will be closed beyond Illinois Governor J.B. Pritzker’s order, which expires April 8, 2020.

However, I want to address a topic that is actually much more important: following and adhering to social distancing guidelines that are currently in place. I have been in contact with our local police department and park district, and D205 is working together with a large number of community organizations to try to provide support across the community during these challenging times. One of the things being reported to us, quite frequently over the last couple days, is that people are congregating in our public spaces in large groups, and this must stop immediately!

I was a baseball player, and I hurt my arm. I know that one of the hardest things to do is not being able to play, but there is a lot more at stake here. Everyone is being asked to chip in. This is just too important. Every life lost is somebody’s parent, somebody’s brother, somebody’s child, somebody’s best friend. We have to take this seriously! I want to thank you in advance for your cooperation. I also want to remind you that our D205 playgrounds are closed. They should not be used. Please follow those guidelines.

The next thing I want to share is something much more uplifting, and that is the community volunteerism that has been on display this past week. The District 205 Foundation has been working with a community group of volunteers, and the work that they have been doing is absolutely outstanding. I want to thank all of you from the bottom of my heart for everything you have been doing to make sure people have basic supplies and enough food to eat. hr.p: Estimadas Familias D205 y Personal,

On behalf of Elmhurst Community Unit District 205, it is my hope that the past few weeks have allowed our families and students to remain healthy and home together as much as possible in these challenging times.

As a reminder, beginning Monday, March 30, Elmhurst Community Unit District 205 will take part in its first Remote Learning/E-Learning Week. Remote Learning/E-Learning Days are designed to serve as official attendance days of school when the students and teachers stay at home due to emergency situations, yet learning continues as students remotely leverage digital tools and engage in teacher-prepared lessons.

In order to successfully support parents in the launch of E-learning as a new process for our District, and to meet the education-related requirements provided by the Illinois State Board of Education (ISBE), the following information is shared for awareness and included in the “Find It Fast” section of the District 205 website.
Each parent and student is requested to please review the following E-Learning Plan Overview and to plan for completing any necessary steps in preparation for March 30th.

p.strong: What can parents expect from the E-learning process?
p.br: An E-Learning Day is not intended to mimic an actual school day in its schedule and design, but rather advance the curriculum and learning to the fullest extent possible while away from school. During an E-Learning Day, students will provide evidence of their learning experiences in various ways based on their grade level.

li.p: Staff members will be working throughout the hours of the standard school day, which includes dedicated time from 10:00 a.m. - 11:30 a.m. to be online daily to answer student (and/or, parent) questions about assignments by email, GoogleHangout, or other District-approved communication platforms.

In addition, the E-learning experience is intended to provide the necessary flexibility for both students and staff, who are also working from home under unique circumstances during this health crisis. Thank you in advance for exhibiting patience when seeking responses and feedback from staff regarding student learning.

Given the evolving challenges and changes resulting from the COVID-19 coronavirus situation, the District 205 E-Learning Plan may adjust to meet shifts at the state level, and to maintain the continuity of instruction for students by adapting instructional strategies. More information will be shared with parents in advance of any adjustments to the e-learning process.

Not all work will necessarily be completed digitally; for example, in grades EC-5, “non-tech” learning opportunities exist within the E-Learning Module Menu. Printed/written assignments can also be handed in upon return to school.
Parents (EC-5) and students (6-12) must submit daily attendance using the processes identified below.

p.b: How does an E-Learning Day work for a student in Early Childhood to 5th grade?
p.br: Attendance: Between 8-11 a.m. parents must complete the Daily E-Learning Attendance Check-In for Parents EC-5. If a parent is unable to check-in a student, the student will be marked as an “Unexcused Absence.”

li.p: Similar to a typical school day, if a student is ill or unable to participate in the E-Learning Day, parents and guardians must call the school attendance line by 11:00am to report an absence from e-learning.

div.p: Assignments: For the week of March 30 - April 3, EC-5 students and parents will be able to access e-learning assignments for five (5) initial E-Learning Days and materials by clicking the E-Learning Module Menu for Grades EC-5 link also located in the “Find It Fast” sections of each school website and the District 205 homepage www.elmhurst205.org.

li.p: After completing all four subject areas, students should send one (1) piece of evidence total per day of e-learning from any of the four (4) subject areas (not all) directly to their teacher - either by email, SeeSaw, or when returning to school.
NOTE: Resources pertaining to any additional days of e-learning will be updated and located in the “Find It Fast” website sections for students and families to access.

p.strong: How does an E-Learning Day work for a student in 6th to 12th grade?
p.br: Attendance: Between 9-11 a.m. students in grades 6 to 12 must use their district-issued Chromebook, home computer, or mobile device to log into Google Classroom at https://classroom.google.com and follow the directions in the Daily E-Learning Attendance Directions for Students 6-12 to submit their attendance. If a student is unable to mark themselves present by 11 a.m., the student will be marked as an “Unexcused Absence.”

li.p: Similar to a typical school day, if a student is ill or unable to participate in the E-Learning Day, parents and guardians must call the school attendance line by 11:00am to report an absence from e-learning.
Assignments: 6-12 students will access e-learning assignments and materials by accessing the corresponding Google Classroom for each class. Teachers will post assignments by 9:00am each day.

p.strong: What if a student needs assistance with assignments?
p.br: Teachers will be working throughout the hours of the school day with dedicated time from 10:00 a.m. to 11:30 a.m. to be online and available for student (or parent) questions about assignments, e-learning, etc. Thank you in advance for exhibiting patience when seeking responses and feedback from staff regarding student learning. Technology Support is also available (below).

p.strong: How will teachers process grades during an E-Learning Day?
p.br: While grading practices and procedures may adjust with regulations from the Illinois State Board of Education (ISBE), the most current guidance issued by ISBE states that “Student work completed during the mandated statewide school closure must not negatively impact a student’s grades or otherwise impact a student’s academic standing. As we do not yet know the full extent of the closure and want to minimize any negative effects on students, schools may allow student work to count during the closure only to increase a student’s academic standing.” Teachers will be receiving procedural guidance on the process for entering work completed remotely by students, and updates will be shared with parents in this process, should changes take place.

p.strong: If needed, how can students and parents receive Technology Support?
p.br: Technical support will be available from school and District 205 technology staff by emailing ELearningHelp@elmhurst205.org. This email is operational on designated E-Learning Days only and actively monitored between 7:30 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. When an email is submitted, a work ticket will be created and assigned to the appropriate staff member.

p.strong: What if a student requires assistance for a disability that may be medical or other?
p.br: For students that are eligible for related services, and whose services are missed due to school closure, staff will first attempt to make up those minutes when the student returns to the school. If those minutes are unable to be made up, the educational team will be in contact with families regarding the consideration of a compensatory service plan.

p.strong: What if a student does not have Internet access on the E-Learning Day?
p.br: District 205 has limited numbers of district-issued Wi-Fi hotspots available for family checkout; these are available by contacting the school principal. If students do not have access to the Internet on an E-Learning Day, families should submit an excused absence similar to existing school policies by calling the school attendance line and leaving a message.

div.p: If unable to obtain Internet service or a technology device on an E-Learning Day, students will not be penalized in any academic manner; students will be provided the opportunity to make up any missed work or complete alternative assignments when returning to school with accommodations and flexibility provided if needed.

Comcast Xfinity WiFi Is Free For Everyone: Xfinity WiFi hotspots across the country are available to anyone for free – including non-Xfinity Internet subscribers. For a map of Xfinity WiFi hotspots, visit www.xfinity.com/wifi. Once at a hotspot, select the “xfinitywifi” network name in the list of available hotspots, and then launch a browser.

AT&T is expanding “Access from AT&T,” with low-cost home internet offering to qualifying households. AT&T will continue to offer internet access for qualifying limited income households at $10 a month through our Access from AT&T program. Click here for more information.

p.strong: What if a student’s District 205-issued device requires repair (hardware, etc.)?
p.br: If your D205-issued Chromebook or iPad has failed and you are unable to use personal technology for E-Learning, opportunities to get a working replacement device (if available) will be provided on a pre-arranged basis.

div.p: You must submit a request in advance using the following form. You will then be contacted to confirm that a repair/replacement is possible; to confirm the drop-off/pick-up time; and, any additional detailed instructions.

p.strong: To request device repair support, please fill out this form:

div.p: As you have questions about the D205 Home Learning/E-Learning Plan, I urge you to contact the teacher(s) or case manager(s) for curricular or instructional questions, and to use the D205 technology help email for technology-related questions at ELearningHelp@elmhurst205.org.

Thank you for your patience and continued support during this challenging time. Plans also are in development in the event that school is not able to resume as anticipated and additional days of home learning/e-learning are needed. We will follow state guidelines regarding “Act of God” days and school closures related to grades and other considerations. Specific information will be communicated when we have clear guidelines as to what those are.

Sincerely,
Dr. David Moyer
Superintendent
